did.unittitle: Hoagy Carmichael Collection

physdesc.extent: 17 linear feet plus artifacts and audiovisual recordings

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Hoagland "Hoagy" Carmichael (1899-1981) was an American jazz composer, pianist, singer, actor, and bandleader. Carmichael grew up in Bloomington, Indiana, and graduated from the Indiana University (IU) School of Law. He composed hundreds of songs over the course of his career, but is best known for composing the music for "Stardust", "Georgia on My Mind", "The Nearness of You", and "Heart and Soul", four of the most-recorded American songs of all time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Hoagy Carmichael Collection represents the largest holding of materials pertaining to Hoagy Carmichael available anywhere in the world.

The Hoagy Carmichael Collection at the Archives of Traditional Music includes music manuscripts, lyric sheets, sound recordings, films and videos, photographs, correspondence, scrapbooks, typescripts, and other memorabilia, totaling more than 3,500 items. The Hoagy Carmichael Collection consists of materials that were in his personal collection, items donated by his family, and items pertaining to Carmichael donated by others-- researchers, musicians and collectors-- from the 1970s to the present.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Some duplicates of donated material removed from collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Other collections related to Hoagy Carmichael can be found in the Indiana University Archives and the Lilly Library.
Additional publications and research material may be accessed in IUScholarWorks.
The Hoagy Carmichael Collection of sound recordings can be found in Media Collections Online.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The majority of this collection was donated to Indiana University by Hoagy Carmichael's estate in 1986. Additional material donated by the estate over time up to the present.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [item], Hoagy Carmichael Collection, Archives of Traditional Music, Indiana University, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: This collection contains materials owned by Hoagy Carmichael and his estate, as well as some materials donated by other scholars, musicians, and collectors.

Joanne Carmichael at 2½ years old in In Hoagy Carmichael's handwriting on back: "My sister Joanne- -the victim of poverty. We couldn't afford a good doctor or good attention and that's when I vowed I would never be broke again in my lifetime. She died from dyptheria and it broke my heart that I didn't have the knowledge or the where withall to help her. It broke my dad's heart, too." (See also 11/4)

Carmichael family portrait, ca. Typewritten on back, "Picture of the Grandmother Mary Emma Campbell Carmichael Family of Bloomington, Indiana, at the home of Grandmother Carmichael, circa 1919. Seated, left to right: Son Howard Clyde, holding grandson James (son of Edwin T.); Grandmother Carmichael below Howard; Edwin T., son, holding daughter Mary Emma; Ruth Souder Carmichael, granddaughter, daughter of Otis; Georgia Eliz., granddaughter, (daughter of Howard); sitting in front her brother Howard Hoagland (Hoagy), grandson, son of Howard; and Margaret Campbell Woodward, sister to Mary Emma. Standing, left to right: Daughter Florence P. Carmichael, Edith, wife of Edwin T.; Mary Lida, wife of Howard Clyde; Peter Milburn, husband of Norine, standing beside him, youngest daughter of Mary Emma; Raymond, son, standing behind Norine; Otis and his second wife Helen. Notes: As of this date 8/6/81 only five are still living: Florence - 96, Norine - 88, James - about 65, Georgia 76, Hoagy - 81."

Matted montage of photographs (top-bottom, l-r):

odd.head: General
odd.p: a)Promotional flyer for Hitch's Happy Harmonists, featuring band members with their instruments. Typed below photograph, "Hitch's Happy Harmonists, Gennett Record Artists. We have completed an arrangement with the management of this wonderful dance orchestra, whereby Indianapolis will be their headquarters during the coming season. This arrangement makes the orchestra more accessible to all points and enables us to offer their services at far less expense than in the past. Bookings for single dates and short engagements are now being made. Address all communications to..."
b) Typed below the photograph, "The above reproduction shows a scene from the traditional burying of the Purdue jinx which is held the night before each Purdue-Indiana context at Bloomington."
c) Seven unidentified musicians posing with their instruments. Handwritten on mat board, "Charlie Davis Orch., South Bend, 1922."
d) Hoagy Carmichael (right) with unidentified man (left) playing trumpet. Handwritten on mat board, "Little Gates."
e) Handwritten on mat board, "'Small divers' Secrest and Porter."
f) Book Nook Commencement Parade, Bloomington, Indiana, 1928. [photograph 3/70; negative 12/5]
g) Hoagy Carmichael with an unidentified man. Handwritten on mat board, "Bent Eagles."
h)Handwritten on mat board, "The great Moenkhaus, grand-daddy of them all."
i) Hoagy Carmichael (2nd from right) posing with other unidentified men on a car. Handwritten on mat board, "More 'Small Divers, W. Palm Beach, 1927."
j) Handwritten on mat board, "The 'Wolverines' at Indiana." [negative 12/5]

k) Newspaper clipping with a picture of the Frank Trumbauer's Orchestra and an announcement of the 1926 Junior Prom. Typed in the clipping, "Frank Trumbauer's eleven-piece orchestra, of St. Louis, will play for the 1926 Junior Prom in the Men's Gymnasium on the night of April 16. The Orchestra makes a specialty of Charleston time as well as other types of music with which Hoosiers are familiar. The Charleston will be permitted in the gymnasium during the Prom, it is announced."
l) Hoagy Carmichael sitting with three unidentified men on the front bumper of a car. Handwritten on mat board, "Dead broke in Miami, 1923."

m) Promotional flyer of the "Old Gold-Paul Whiteman Special" Orchestra. Typed below the photograph, "En route from New York to Los Angeles, broadcasting from coast-to-coast, the Old Gold-Paul Whiteman Hour, sponsored by P. Lorillard Company, makers of Old Gold cigarettes."
n) Leon "Bix" Beiderbecke (right) and Frank Trambauer in Kansas. Handwritten on mat board, "'Bix' and 'Tram.'" [negative 12/5]
o) Promotional flyer for the "Palais Garden Orchestra."

did.unittitle: Press clipping from the Indianapolis Sunday Star of Hoagy and Ruth Carmichael sitting at a table in the "Star Dust Café." Typed below photograph, "'Star Dust' Author Visits Old Friends, Hoagy Carmichael, song-writer extraordinary, late of Indianapolis and Indiana University and now Broadway and Hollywood, recently revisited Bloomington where he first conceived the popular melody 'Star Dust.' Mr. and Mrs. Carmichael are shown at the Star Dust restaurant, christened in Hoagy's honor, holding a jam session with old friends from Bloomington and Indiana University. (Everett Mitchell)"

Hoagy Carmichael (kneeling, far left) in a group photograph of an ASCAP celebration, called "Cavalcade of American music." At far left, Howard Hanson and Charles Wakefield Cadman. George M. Handy (to Cohen's left), Irving Berlin and Deems Taylor (both kneeling on Hoagy's left), Mack Gordon (front row facing slightly to his left), Harold Arlen (next to Gordon), Jerome Kern (next to Arlen), and Johnny Mercer (front row, far right).

B. Awards/Certificates, Memberships, Trophies/Plaques
Awards/Certificates, Memberships
Awards/Certificates
James J. Jeffries School of Boxing. Certificate of victory. "...defeated Ralph Malone in an Amateur Boxing Bout by decision." Signed by James J. Jeffries.
United States Treasury Department. "In appreciation of services rendered in behalf of the War Finance Program..."
State of Indiana, Executive Department. Proclamation for Hoagy Carmichael-Stardust Road Day. Mimeograph copy of official proclamation
Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Certificate of nomination for Academy Award of Merit for Outstanding Achievement for song "Ole Buttermilk Sky" from the film "Canyon Passage"
Box Office. Blue ribbon award for "best picture of the month for the whole family" to HC as Butch Engle in the film "The Best Years of Our Lives" Blue ribbon on gold-colored cardboard background.
Hollywood Motion Picture Relief Fund, Inc. For service in the Screen Guild Players broadcast of Thursday Certificate in folded holder.
United States Army. In appreciation for distinguished performance as guest star of "Voice of the Army," a radio production of the U.S. Army and the U.S. Air Force
The Railroad Hour (Association of American Railroads). In appreciation for his musical contribution to "a whole generation of our times - for truly American songs...."
Bob Hope-Bing Crosby Olympic Telethon for the United States Olympic Fund. In appreciation of his services in Telethon to raise money for American Athletes to compete in the Olympics in Helsinki.
Indiana University. Distinguished Alumni Service Award, for outstanding achievement as an artist
Endorsements, Inc. Annual Big Name Award, most wanted name for testimonial advertising
Colorado Centennial Commission. Colorado "Rush to the Rockies" Centennial, for outstanding contributions which have brought recognition to the state

City of Indianapolis. Proclamation of "Stardust over Indiana Day" on given in thanks to HC and other artists performing with the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra on said date. Photocopy of original proclamation.
Board of Directors of the Indiana State Symphony. Tribute of recognition given in appreciation of assistance with the Stardust over Indiana Concert on
The Elgin Golf Club. Election to non-resident membership in the Elgin Golf Club of Elgin, Morayshire, Scotland. "Given in recognition of his [HC's] affinity for the royal and ancient game [golf]"
State of Indiana Supreme Court. Card in remembrance that on November 4, 1927 HC was admitted to practice law in Indiana. 3½" x 2½" card

Indiana University Alumni of Palm Springs. Given during the Indiana University sesquicentennial to HC "for his illustrious contributions to his Alma Mater." Hand-made of wax paper and gold-colored foil.

City of Los Angeles. Resolution that the Los Angeles City Council "...does hereby commend HC as one of the world's great composers and expresses its appreciation for his contributions to the world of music...." Unsigned copy of the resolution. See also the original plaque.
Kappa Sigma Fraternity. Certificate of fifty years of membership in the Kappa Sigma Fraternity Gold-colored paper.
Indiana State Senate. Resolution in memory of HC. Signed by three State Senators and the Secretary of the Senate

National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. Two awards for induction of "Star Dust" into the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences Hall of Fame One certificate for HC as artist and one for HC as songwriter. In a white folder.
Hollywood Canteen. "In appreciation of your loyal services to the Hollywood Canteen."

Veterans Administration. Two certificates of appreciation for outstanding service to U.S. war veterans in making possible the official recorded radio series "Here's to Veterans." Second copy in recognition of "Here's to Veterans IX Edition."
Membership cards
State of Colorado. Permit to "pass at will through the Indian Country or to remain in this territory throughout the year"
Songwriter's Hall of Fame. Valid until June 30, 1970. Accompanied by note acknowledging HC as a charter member in good standing. Signed by Johnny Mercer.
American Federation of Television & Radio. Membership card. Expiration date, April 30, 1971.
Kappa Sigma Fraternity. Fifty-year membership
Screen Actors Guild. Expiration date, October 31, 1973.
Songwriter's Hall of Fame. Expiration date June 30, 1974.
California Republican Party. Membership in California's Republican Party
Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Certificate for
Don the Beachcomber. Simulated credit card.
Society of the Friends of Music of Indiana. Lifetime membership.
Trophies and Plaques
Erskine Johnson Award. "The man who writes the songs America loves to sing, the composer of 'Stardust'." Wood, with metal statue of a woman holding a torch.
Bel-Air Golf Club. Hole-in-one trophy Golf ball on silver stand.
State of Indiana. Celebrating Indiana's sesquicentennial. Wood and tile plaque.
City of Los Angeles. Resolution to commend and recognize HC as one of the world's greatest performers. 15" x 23" plaque.
City of Denver. Tribute to HC in honor of his visit to Denver. Plastic, with 1921 one-dollar coin.
City of Indianapolis. Key to the city. 7" metal key.
Gary Chamber of Commerce. Great Living Hoosier Award. Wood plaque in the shape of Indiana.
Mount Kenya Safari Club. Wood plaque with sculpture of an elephant.
Unknown. In appreciation for composing the NFL "Li'l Pro Marching Song." Wood plaque with metal football helmet.
Wood plaque with coat of arms for HC. On back: "Produced exclusively for the Halberts. Artist: B Free."
Hoagy Carmichael Room
State of Indiana. Distinguished Hoosier Award. Signed by Governor Matthew E. Welsh. 14½ x 10.
Janie and Wad Allen. Distinguished Best Man Service Award. 4¼ x 1½.
National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. Grammy Award for "Star Dust," recorded by HC and His Pals for Gennett in 1927. 7 x 9 x 4.
Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Nomination for Academy Award for HC and Johnny Mercer for "In the Cool, Cool, Cool, of the Evening." Framed certificate.
Songwriter's Hall of Fame. Statuette of a piano. Award for induction into the Songwriter's Hall of Fame. 5¼ x 5⅛ x 2¾.
American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers. 50 year ASCAP membership certificate. 14⅛ x 11⅛.
Indiana University. Honorary Doctor of Music degree. 11½ x 9.
Indiana University. IU Distinguished Alumni Service Award. 7¼ x 3½.
State of Indiana, Council of the Sagamores of the Wabash. "Sagamore of the Wabash" declaration, mounted on wood. Signed by Governor Matthew E. Welsh.
Indiana University. Bachelor of Laws degree. Framed. 21 x 17¼.
